rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 16–31
rsbNotes.text: 16:1–31:13 These chapters narrate David’s rise to power and Saul’s fall from power and his death. David’s rise is marked by his anointing by Samuel and his time in Saul’s service (chs. 16–18), his flight from Saul (chs. 19–23), his avoidance of bloodguilt (chs. 24–26), and his escape to the Philistines (chs. 27–31).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:1
rsbNotes.text: 26:1 Ziphites came to Saul. See note 23:19.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:6
rsbNotes.text: 26:6 Abishai the son of Zeruiah. See note 2 Sam. 2:18.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:8
rsbNotes.text: 26:8 God has given your enemy. See note 24:4.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:9
rsbNotes.text: 26:9 against the Lord’s anointed. See 24:6 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:10
rsbNotes.text: 26:10 the Lord will strike him. David’s words express an assurance gained or at least reinforced by the Lord’s recent dealings with Nabal (25:38, 39).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:12
rsbNotes.text: 26:12 a deep sleep from the Lord. David’s survival and ultimate success are divinely overseen and directed (see also 30:2, 19 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:19
rsbNotes.text:
26:19 the heritage of the Lord. See note 2 Sam. 20:19.

Go, serve other gods. David means that he was expelled to live among aliens, away from the people of God.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:20
rsbNotes.text: 26:20 a partridge. The partridge, whose name in Hebrew means “caller,” is a cleverly chosen name for David, who stands on the crest of a mountain and “calls” (vv. 13, 14).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:21
rsbNotes.text: 26:21 I have sinned. Return. David’s response to Saul’s confession and invitation (v. 22) indicates he doubts Saul’s sincerity; compare Samuel’s response to a similar invitation by Saul in 15:24–26.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 26:25
rsbNotes.text: 26:25 Blessed be you, my son David. Saul’s behavior is erratic, and David trusts neither his confessions nor his blessings (27:1; see note 24:20).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:1
rsbNotes.text: 27:1 one day by the hand of Saul. Despite recently learned lessons of faith (26:10), David tires of being a fugitive in constant danger and gives in to the human fear that Saul will eventually succeed in destroying him. David’s anxiety may be heightened since he and his men have their families with them (v. 3). For the second time (21:10), David seeks refuge among Israel’s archenemies, the Philistines.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:2
rsbNotes.text: 27:2 Achish. Now that the rift between David and Saul is conspicuous and indisputable, Achish readily accepts David’s presence, doubtless hoping to benefit from David’s allegiance in his own struggles against Saul (29:6).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:3
rsbNotes.text: 27:3 his two wives. See note 25:40–44.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:5
rsbNotes.text: 27:5 in the royal city with you. While David’s request to be assigned to “one of the country towns” is ostensibly based on a desire not to burden the royal city, it promises him a greater freedom of action by removing him from the eyes of Achish (vv. 8–11).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:6
rsbNotes.text:
27:6 Ziklag. Listed among the cities of Judah (Josh. 15:31; 19:5), ancient Ziklag may have been at Tel esh-Shariah, fifteen miles northwest of Beersheba. Once an Israelite possession, Ziklag was under Philistine control at this time.

kings of Judah. This expression is from the viewpoint of a time after the division of Israel into the northern and southern kingdoms (1 Kin. 12).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:8
rsbNotes.text:
27:8 Geshurites. Neighbors of the Philistines (Josh. 13:2), these people are not the same as the Geshurites from east of the Jordan (Josh. 13:11; 2 Sam. 15:8; 1 Chr. 2:23). David’s wife, Absalom’s mother (2 Sam. 3:3), was from the Geshurites east of the Jordan.

Girzites. Not identifiable; Gezer is quite distant.

Amalekites. See note 15:2.

Shur. See note 15:7.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:9
rsbNotes.text: 27:9 leave neither man nor woman alive. David’s practice would conceal his double-dealings from Achish (v. 11). Whether it was right is doubtful at best in the absence of any indication that the Lord had ordered his actions.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:10
rsbNotes.text:
27:10 David would say. This is not the first time David thinks it necessary to deceive (20:6; 21:2 and notes; cf. 16:2 note).

the Negeb of Judah. See 2 Sam. 24:7; 2 Chr. 28:18. The large southern region of Israel, the Negeb, extended from Beersheba south to the Gulf of Aqaba.

Jerahmeelites. 1 Chr. 2:9–15 mentions Jerahmeel as a descendant of Judah through Hezron and as a brother of Ram, an ancestor of David.

Kenites. Kenites and Jerahmeelites are mentioned together in 30:29.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 27:12
rsbNotes.text: 27:12 Achish trusted David. Achish was deceived by David’s pretense of raiding villages in Judah and its environs.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:1
rsbNotes.text: 28:1 Understand. Achish points out that his benevolence to David has certain strings attached. The same Hebrew phrase is used in Solomon’s warning to Shimei in 1 Kin. 2:37, 42.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:2
rsbNotes.text:
28:2 what your servant can do. The irony of David’s ambiguous answer (will David fight for or against him?) has a counterpoint in the perhaps unconscious irony of Achish’s reply.

my bodyguard for life. Presumably Achish’s offer is contingent on David’s performance in battle. The Hebrew term used by Achish for “bodyguard” means literally “keeper of my head,” an unfortunate choice of words in view of David’s treatment of Goliath (17:49–54).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:3
rsbNotes.text:
28:3 Samuel had died. The death of Samuel signals the passing of an era.

the mediums and the necromancers. Although Saul’s expulsion of mediums and necromancers is fully in keeping with Mosaic law (Lev. 19:31; 20:6, 27; Deut. 18:11), it is only a partial proof of zeal for the religion of Israel. Saul’s consultation of a medium is a clear indication of unfaithfulness and disobedience (1 Chr. 10:13), while Lev. 20:6 says that such a person is to be “cut . . . off from among his people.”

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:4
rsbNotes.text:
28:4 Shunem. Located just southwest of the hill of Moreh and sixteen miles southwest of the Sea of Chinnereth (Galilee). Shunem was the site of the Philistine camp on the eve of the battle in which Saul died (ch. 31).

Gilboa. This is probably the mountain range that begins five miles south of Shunem and extends south along the eastern edge of the plain of Jezreel. It could also be a village located in the heart of the Gilboa range eleven miles south of Shunem. See 29:1 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:5
rsbNotes.text: 28:5 his heart trembled greatly. See 17:11 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:6
rsbNotes.text:
28:6 the Lord did not answer him. Saul’s inquiry is prompted by anxiety (v. 5), not piety, and the Lord’s refusal to answer is reminiscent of the threat of 8:18.

by dreams, or by Urim, or by prophets. Saul rejected the Lord and as a consequence was rejected by the Lord (15:23 and note). This cut him off from the usual means of divine inquiry. Whereas David had the prophet Gad in his retinue (22:5), it is unlikely that a true prophet accompanied Saul. Moreover, the authentic ephod containing the Urim and Thummim (2:28 note) had come into David’s possession through Abiathar (23:6).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:7
rsbNotes.text:
28:7 Seek out for me a woman who is a medium. His purge of the land notwithstanding (v. 3 note), Saul seems to have no doubt that a medium can be found, and his attendants can name one immediately.

En-dor. Josh. 17:11, 12 attests to a persistent Canaanite influence at En-dor, which was about five miles north of Shunem (v. 4 note). Saul’s recourse to En-dor took him behind Philistine lines.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:12
rsbNotes.text: 28:12 the woman saw Samuel. Probably this was Samuel, and not merely an apparition. The consternation of the medium shows that the figure was something outside her usual experience of magic arts. The narrator calls it simply “Samuel,” and what the figure says is consistent with Samuel’s pronouncements when alive (especially ch. 15). For some reason the Lord allowed Samuel to visit Saul. It is clear from the medium’s reaction that she could not compel him to appear.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:14
rsbNotes.text: 28:14 Saul knew that it was Samuel. Apparently Saul recognized Samuel when the woman described his mantle. Robes have symbolized the fate of Saul’s kingship in a variety of ways, and mention of Samuel’s mantle recollects the devastating pronouncement of 15:28 (see also 18:4; 24:4–6).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:19
rsbNotes.text: 28:19 you and your sons shall be with me. That is, among the dead (31:2–4).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:23
rsbNotes.text: 28:23 I will not eat. See note 1:7.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Sam 28:24
rsbNotes.text: 28:24 fattened calf. Much has changed since Saul’s first encounter with Samuel, when he was designated as the one to deliver Israel from the Philistines (9:16) and was treated to a festal meal by the prophet (9:22–24). Now in his last encounter with Samuel, on the eve of his own death and the crushing Philistine defeat of Israel, Saul is treated to a fatted calf by a medium.
